Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Unique Skinks of New Guinea: Diversity, Systematics, and Malaria Parasites
Award.AbstractNarration:
On the island of New Guinea, some extraordinary lizards have green blood, due to high levels of biliverdin, a bile pigment, which overwhelms the color of their red blood cells. In humans and other vertebrates, biliverdin (and bilirubin) are toxic waste products that cause jaundice and are associated with pathology in newborns and diseases such as Gilbert's and Crigler-Najjar syndromes. As the concentration of biliverdin in these lizards would cause jaundice and death in other animals, the adaptive significance of their high bile pigment levels is unknown. One hypothesis is that it is an anti-parasitic strategy. Lizards are hosts to malaria parasites but preliminary data collected by the PI's show a trend towards reduced levels of malaria infection in green-blooded lizards. The goals of this project are to conduct fieldwork at nine locales in Papua New Guinea and to use a large number of tissue and blood samples already in hand to obtain better estimates of the diversity and relationships of skinks and their malaria parasites, in order to more conclusively test this hypothesis. Thus, this project will make numerous novel contributions to systematics, biodiversity, and parasitology.

The broader impacts of this project will include development of middle/high school curriculum materials, training of undergraduate and graduate students, and various international partnerships. As no other animals have ever been found that can survive this level of biliverdin in their blood, the study may ultimately provide some clues to better understand jaundice and in doing so contribute to biomedicine and economic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On the island of New Guinea, just north of Australia, some extraordinary lizards have green blood. This atypical blood coloration is due to high levels of the green bile pigment biliverdin, which overwhelms the bright crimson color of their normal red blood cells. In humans and other vertebrates, bile pigments are toxic waste products that cause jaundice. Many newborn babies and adults with liver disease suffer from jaundice. The concentration of biliverdin in these lizards would cause jaundice and death in humans and other animals. The adaptive significance of high bile pigment levels in these extraordinary lizards is unknown. The island of New Guinea has been identified as megadiverse and much of the plant and animal life are found nowhere else in the world. New Guinea is the world’s largest and highest tropical island, and though it occupies less than 1% of the Earth’s land surface, it is estimated that as much as 6% of the world’s total biodiversity is found there. Although poorly understood and inadequately described, the vast diversity of biological life on New Guinea is a result of the island’s diverse topography, extensive range of habitat types, and complex geological history. The major goals of this project are: (1) to conduct fieldwork in New Guinea to collect a large number of tissues and blood samples to better understand the unusual physiology of these lizards, (2) to resolve the relationships of New Guinea lizards to understand the origin of green blood.

In 2018 we published a seminal paper in Science Advances resolving New Guinea lizard relationships using a next-generation DNA sequencing approach. Surprisingly, we found strong support for four independent origins of green blood in New Guinea lizards. The repeated evolution of this extraordinary physiological trait suggests that there may be some strong selective force causing recurrent origins. As no other animals have ever been found that can survive this level of biliverdin in their blood, our results may ultimately provide some clues to better understand jaundice and in doing so contribute to biomedicine and economic development. This research has made numerous novel contributions to systematics, biodiversity, parasitology, and evolutionary biology as well as to lay the foundation for future work on this exceptional study system. Our Science Advances paper received a large amount of popular press attention including radio interviews on National Public Radio interview, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, as well as numerous websites and newspapers (Associated Press and Reuters).

The project provided direct training for several graduate and undergraduate students. One graduate student who worked on this project received an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant for her dissertation work and she is now an assistant professor at the University of Louisiana at Monroe. Another graduate student is an underrepresented first generation college student and he received a NSF Graduate Research Fellowship and will be graduating next year. One of the undergraduate students trained is completing her honors thesis on gene families in reptiles and will be graduating next year.

Fieldwork resulted in 2,041 vouchered specimens, 2,041 tissues, 82 digital recordings, and over 5,000 photographs. A total of 30+ new species were discovered (23 published to date). 11 presentations at national and international meetings were given and 22 papers are published as a result of this grant.
